title: 105_hr1373
content: The Act titled "Early Learning and Opportunity Act of 1997" is cited as the short title. The findings section follows. The Congress finds that the first 3 years of life are crucial for brain development, emotional growth, and overall well-being of a child. Research indicates that experiences during this period significantly impact individuals throughout their lives. Additionally, one in 3 victims of physical abuse is under 1 year old, and nearly half of infants in the US lack necessary resources for growth. High-quality care from adults is essential for child development. More than 50 percent of working women lack paid maternity leave, unlike 30 developing countries. Five million children under 3 are in care while parents work, with limited affordable child care options available. Less than 20% of child care services for very young children are of good quality, with nearly 50% being substandard and affecting children's development and safety. Families with children under 3 years old are the largest group living in poverty, with 25% of them below the poverty line and at risk for malnutrition, poor health, and maltreatment. These children are less likely to receive the necessary care for normal growth and development. The Act aims to enhance child care services for children under 3 years old, improve affordability, assist families in nurturing their children, and enhance existing programs for these services. Early Learning and Opportunity Grants are provided for these services. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may grant funds to eligible States to improve child care services for very young children and support services for their families. Priority is given to states that minimize administrative costs and coordinate activities with child care providers for children aged 3-6. The State, through legislative or executive action, aims to reduce duplication and barriers in providing child care services. Providers will be reimbursed at rates reflecting higher costs for accredited providers and for caring for very young children. SEC. 102. ELIGIBILITY FOR GRANTS. To be eligible for a grant under section 101, a State must submit an application that includes a plan to improve quality of child care services and licensing standards for providers of child care services for very young children. The application must be prepared in consultation with child care service providers and family support service providers in the State. The curr_chunk focuses on improving licensing standards, staff qualifications, training, and salaries for caregivers of child care services, including those for children with special needs. It aims to enhance enforcement of licensing standards and support advanced training for caregivers. The curr_chunk focuses on improving accessibility, quality, affordability, and support services for families with very young children. It also aims to enhance coordination of existing Federal and State programs for these families. The grant application must ensure that no more than 70% of the costs will be covered by the grant and federal funds, it should supplement non-Federal funds, the State must contribute at least 30% of the grant amount, and the grant must be administered by the designated lead agency. The grant application must be administered by the designated lead agency and contain information required by the Secretary. SEC. 103. The Secretary will develop a model training program for child care providers' employees based on existing requirements. The program will be voluntary and provide technical assistance for implementation. SEC. 104 defines key terms. SEC. 104. Definitions include terms like caregiver, family support services, Secretary, and very young children. SEC. 105 authorizes $360,000,000 for fiscal years 1998-2002. SEC. 201. References in this title to amendments or repeals shall be considered as referring to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. SEC. 202. Taxation of income of controlled foreign corporations related to imported property. The amendment to section 954 defines imported property income as income derived from manufacturing, producing, growing, or extracting imported property. The term 'imported property' refers to property imported into the United States by a controlled foreign corporation or a related person, including property imported by unrelated persons. It excludes foreign oil and gas extraction income or foreign oil related income. The term 'imported property' includes property imported into the United States by unrelated persons if it was expected to be imported or used as a component in other imported property. The term 'import' in this subsection refers to entering or withdrawing property from warehouse for consumption or use, including the right to use an intangible. The controlled foreign corporation or related person can sell, lease, or rent property for use outside the United States before substantial use in the US, or use it as a component in other property that is then sold, leased, or rented. The term 'import' in this subsection refers to entering or withdrawing property from warehouse for consumption or use, including the right to use an intangible. The controlled foreign corporation or related person can sell, lease, or rent property for use outside the United States before substantial use in the US, or use it as a component in other property that is then sold, leased, or rented. Any grant of the right to use an intangible in the United States is subject to limitations on foreign tax credit for imported property income. The term 'unrelated person' means any person who is not a related person with respect to the controlled foreign corporation. Foreign base company sales income shall not include any imported property income. The tax code is amended to include imported property income as a new category of income. Imported property income is defined as any income received or accrued by a person that would be considered imported property income. Look-through rules apply to this definition. The tax code is amended to include imported property income as a new category of income. Look-through rules are updated to apply to this definition. The tax code amendments apply to taxable years of foreign corporations starting after December 31, 1996, and to taxable years of U.S. shareholders that coincide with those of foreign corporations. Amendments in subsection (c) apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1996. The Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 is amended to reduce the coverage threshold from 50 to 20 employees. The effective date of this amendment is 120 days after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, the Head Start Act is amended to authorize appropriations of $4.9 billion for fiscal year 1999, $5.5 billion for fiscal year 2000, $6.1 billion for fiscal year 2001, and $6.7 billion for fiscal year 2002. SEC. 402 of the Head Start Act is amended to increase training and technical assistance funds from 2 percent to 3 percent. Additionally, programs for families with infants and toddlers will receive increased funding over the years 1998 to 2002. SEC. 403 states that these amendments will take effect on October 1, 1997.
